answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
Hi Leslie,
In my opinion, the best way to get a basic reading of the overall "health" of a community is through the use of a citizen survey, such as the National Citizen Survey, offered by the National Research Center.  Of course, it only measures citizens perceptions, but in a lot of ways, that is the bottom line for governments.

answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
Thomas makes a great suggestion. Having a benchmark to compare against gives you real information. If you had a question such as "Overall I think Anytown is a good place to live" and got a 65% Agree & Strongly Agree rating, you might think that sounds really good. But you might feel differently if you found out that other cities of a similar size/demographic average a 80% rating.
Even if you don't go with a comparative instrument, you need to be prepared to do repeated on-going measurement on the same questions to tell you how things are progressing over time.

answers.author: Rebecca VanRegenmorter
answers.text:
Leslie, ICMA has a partnership with the National Citizen Survey that was mentioned above. You can find information about the National Citizen Survey here: http://icma.org/en/results/home/surveying/national_citizen_survey
Also, the ICMA Center for Performance Measurement offers comparative data on 18 different local government service areas. For more information on our Center you can visit our website at icma.org/performance or contact me (rvanregenmorter@icma.org or 202-962-3585).
